head.title: This Is Not Your Parents' Bathroom

hedline.hl1: This Is Not Your Parents' Bathroom

abstract.p: Tiles designed by Jorge Pardo will adorn Dia Center for the Arts and Tardini, SoHo retail store; photos (S)

block.p: Tile is the focal point of two new stores. When the Dia Center for the Arts reopens on Sept. 13, the bookstore and gallery will be tiled in dazzling colors, below left. Jorge Pardo, a Los Angeles artist who designed the tilework, believes the all-white gallery space is a cliche. ''I wanted to set up a different aesthetic,'' he said. ''The raw material of the space is color.'' The gallery will exhibit ''Jorge Pardo: Project,'' a show of his tiles and art, through June, 2002. Trompe l'oeil Bisazza tiles arranged to look like the belly of an alligator turn up at Tardini, a new SoHo shop that sells handbags made from alligator, lizard and python. Fabio Novembre, an architect from Milan who designed the shop, is the art director of Bisazza, a tile manufacturer in Vicenza, Italy. Dia is at 548 West 22nd Street; Tardini is at 142 Wooster Street (near Houston Street.)
